Predominantly in Auckland, but actually throughout New Zealand. Here, we are already 50 percent Maori, Pacifican and Asian. 44 percent are not born in the New Zealand. And we have over two hundred ethnicities. Now the definition academically of super-diversity is 25 percent are born in New Zealand a hundred ethnicities. So we are almost double that number already. And Auckland will continue to become younger and browner as Angela-saxon population ages and shrinks. So the megatrend here is not age. And the megatrend here is not urbanization. The megatrend is demography. It’s ethnicity. And we need to get our head around that because most of the benefits from super-diversity that we, as a country, are enjoying at the moment such as great renovation, productivity and investment increase New Zealand’s financial capital, whereas the most of the challenges from super-diversity adversely affect New Zealand’s social capital. However, if you don’t mitigate the challenges to your social capital, you are not gonna maximize sustainably the diversity dividing benefits for your financial capital.

title: The history of laundry 真题音频
answer: Sample answer:The lecture talks about a domestic appliance, which is the washing machine. The evolution of the washing machine is a representative example of changing domestic life. Previous washing process could take an entire day of back-breaking labor in the household. In 1846, a patented washing machine imitated the human hand moving cloth over a washboard was invented, and the first electric clothes washers were introduced into America in 1900. (69 words)
passage:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MRMNM_iXMe0
真实考试没有这么长，前半部分少了几个点，包括redefine women 那一段没有。从后面back breaking 开始基本差不多。
Here in the wagon barn are some of the most important inventions in human history. Sure, you can see examples here of the wheel or the automobile, but the inventions I'm talking about are the domestic appliances that allowed for increased leisure time and redefined gender roles in society. To a degree as never seen before in human history, the evolution of the washing machine as demonstrated in this barn is a representative example of this changing domestic life. For many centuries, sailors used to place their clothing in a cloth bag, tie the back to a rope and throw it overboard, letting the ship drag it for hours. The principle was simple: force water through the clothes to remove the dirt. But in the household before running water and electricity washing clothes took a staggering amount of labor. To wash, boil and rinse a single load of clothes could take 50 gallons of water, which had to be hand carried from a pump or well. hand-wringing, rubbing and lifting the clothes could expose women to caustic substances in the soaps. The whole process for a households laundry could take an entire day or more of back-breaking labor. In 1846, a patented washing machine imitated the human hand moving cloth over a washboard by using a lever to rub the clothes between two rib surfaces. This machine was sold in the U.S. as late as 1927. The first electric clothes washers in which a motor rotated the tub were introduced into America about 1900.

title: Curator 真题音频
answer: Sample answer: Museums create a very particular kind of history that museums are good at creating and communicating. Curators try to understand the culture of the material as evidence of other people's lives. Unlike other kinds of historians like filmmakers and photographers, curators regard objects as evidence of the past and try to arrange objects in meaningful ways called exhibitions. (58 words)
passage:
原音频：https://www.nma.gov.au/audio/uncategorised/curating-australian-histories 
[01:40 - 02:50]
So I am going to talk today really mostly about what I do as a curator here at the National Museum, but I want to try and draw some kind of generalities from that in terms of how these series of curatorial practices, if you like tools and techniques and methods that I think could be of interest to your students and of interest to you in developing extension history courses. I want to talk about what I do as a curator and then from that also talk a little bit about the kinds of history that I think museums are particularly good at creating and communicating. I think this is something I'd really like to discuss because I think it's not necessarily very well understood that museums as Dave insisted by putting up my quote in his slide, is that I think museums create a very particular kind of history. It's not the kind of history that gets created in books or in dating films or in compositions, it's a very particular kind of history that grows out of the fact that museums are centrally interested and defined by their collections. I should say that's not an uncontested view of museums but it's certainly my view of museums.
[05:28 - 06:33]
So curators try to understand material culture as evidence of other people's lives as a means to try to understand other people - what they look like, what they did, how they made a living, what they hoped for in their lives, how they tried to construct their world and why they made particular choices. And one way in which curators differ from other historians is therefore in terms of how we interrogate the past, what elements we use to communicate the past. Most academic historians are trained very much in the discipline of words and they concentrate on words still today I think although it's changing a little bit. If you go through university history, I think primarily you are encouraged to draw on things like archival accounts, manuscripts and now oral histories, and most of that work is actually promulgated in the form of books.
There are also other kinds of historians. Obviously, filmmakers and photographers concentrate on creating images of the world and arranging them in meaningful sequences, but curators attend to objects. We look at objects as evidence of the past and try to arrange objects in meaningful ways called exhibitions.

title: Instinct 真题音频
answer: Sample answer: Instinct is a set of behaviors that are both unlearned and set in motion as the result of some environmental triggers. Firstly, instincts are in relation to motivation. Secondly, instincts are present across species and consistent within individual species. In terms of instinct and a reflex, both are types of unlearned behavior, but a reflex is a simple reaction while an instinct is a complex set of behaviors. (68 words)
passage:
Instinct is a term used to describe a set of behaviors that are both unlearned and set in motion as the result of some environmental trigger. Instincts are also often discussed in relation to motivation since they can also occur in response to an organism's need to satisfy some innate internal drive tied to survival.
Instincts are present across species and are consistent within individual species. In other words, many different species rely on instincts, and if one member of a species possesses an instinct, then they all do.
Before we move into a discussion of specific types of instincts, it is important to distinguish the difference between an instinct and a reflex. Both are types of unlearned behavior that tend to serve a survival purpose. The difference is that a reflex is a typically a simple reaction or a response to an environmental trigger whereas an instinct is a much more complex set of behaviors.
For instance, an example of a reflex would be when a baby turns his head toward an object that is pressed against one cheek in an effort to nurse. The head turn is a simple reactionary process. An instinct would be the manner in which a mother bird regurgitates her food to feed her young in response to their signals of hunger. Both are reactions to environmental cues; however, the mother bird must engage in a series of much more complex behaviors in order to respond to the cues the environment is providing her.

title: Fast radio burst 真题音频
answer: Sample answer: The lecture is about a fast radio burst which is a very fast burst of radio waves. It starts and stops quickly, and these bursts are a real mystery because there are many questions about them and we don't have an answer for it. There are many theories on what makes them. Finally, by using a fantastic telescope, we can find these bursts much more quickly. (68 words)
passage:
A fast radio burst is very much like what it sounds. It's a very fast burst of radio waves. It comes from outer space, a long way away. And by fast, I mean really fast. So it starts and stops in about a thousandth of a second, so you click your fingers, and it's finished. Fast radio bursts are a real mystery. We don't exactly understand where they come from, or what actually makes them. And there's a lot of open questions that we really don't have an answer for. There are probably more theories about what makes fast radio bursts, than there are actual detections of these things. So since 2007 we've only had 20, but there are probably 30 or 40 different theories on what makes them. The most interesting thing about this burst is the fact that we found it with the Australian square kilometre ray path finder. So that is, it wasn't really obvious that we would be able to do this, as well as we ended up being able to do it. So this telescope is really a fantastic telescope. 
In fact it's probably the best telescope on the planet at the moment for finding these bursts. So whereas in the past it's taken ten years to find twenty bursts, once we're really going with this new instrument, we'll be able to find them much more quickly. One or two every week.

title: Cognitive Advantages of Bilingualism 真题音频
answer: Sample answer: Two groups of seven-month-old babies who speak one language continue looking for the previous position as if nothing had changed, while the other group of bilingual babies very quickly notices that the puppet has changed its position. To sum up, people are really at an advantage when they speak more than one language, especially if that happens from birth or at least in the first five years of life. (69 words)
passage:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W-ml2dD4SIk [2:18-3:46]
So, there is an example comes from the other end of life and has to do with what's called wonder babies. This was a study which was done a few years ago in Trieste which is basically at the border on Slovenia and Italy. So there are a lot of Italians and there are a lot of Slovenians and there are of course a lot of mixed marriages. What they did was they took three groups of babies, all babies were seven months old so there were a bunch of Italian speaking babies, bunch of Slovenian speaking babies and a bunch of Italian-Slovenian babies from mixed families. They showed those babies various puppets and then they switched the situation. Typically when the seven-month-old baby is used to particular setting and the situation switches, it takes them a little while to regroup. So turned out that seven-month-old Italian and seven-month-old Slovenian babies would get used to the puppet appearing on the right, and then when the puppet would appear on the left they would continue looking to the right as if nothing had changed. Whereas the bilingual babies very quickly would turn their head and notice that the puppet has changed its position. So again an indication that all other factors being equal. There was something made those babies more advantageous, and these are just a couple of examples indicating that people do really improve when they speak more than one language especially if that happens from birth or at least in the first five years of life.

title: Precision
postContent:
回忆要点1：precision and clarity 说话要understandable. Our words are not clear 要有一个second standard. They don't say anything, and it should be understandable. It must be clear correct and detailed. 别人问你想吃什么，你不能只回答yes的那个

回忆要点2：Some people speak words without connecting them to any meaning. Your words should be understandable, so they must be clear. Correct and with enough details, which means precision is important and required. For example, if you are asked do you want to eat, you should specify what you want to eat instead of simply saying yes. Thus, if you want everyone to understand you well, you should say everything clearly.

title: Globalization V2 (原音频）
answer: Sample answer：Globalization is overused and misunderstood, but the starting point of it is the industries and markets that globalize, rather than countries. So, it can be understood as the integration of economic activities across borders. Moreover, globalization matters because it means the rise of inter-connectedness between countries and markets across the world, which can be proved by the example of the financial crash of 2007 to 2008.(66 words)
passage: 原文：Globalization is an overused and often misunderstood concept. We hear it all the time on news broadcasts and in any type of public discussion. But the starting point for understanding globalization is that it is industries and markets that globalize, not countries. That's why it's helpful to think of Globalization as 'the integration of economic activities across borders'. But why does globalization matter? I would argue globalization matters because it means the rise of inter-connectedness between countries and markets across the world. For example, one of the reasons why the financial crash of 2007/2008 was so serious was because the financial and banking systems of countries around the world have become so closely interconnected with the globalization of markets.

I would argue globalization matters because it means the rise of inter-connectedness between countries and markets across the world. For example, one of the reasons why the financial crash of 2007/2008 was so serious was because the financial and banking systems of countries around the world have become so closely interconnected with the globalization of markets.

title: DNA & RNA
answer: Sample answer:Biology is responsible for profound insights about the world. All lives on the earth are related and similar to one to another. For example, all life forms rely on DNA and RNA for storing and transmitting in using their genetic and inherited information, and they are all based on the cell which is the fundamental building blocks of all organisms. These organisms conduct metabolism and have the similar basic chemistry. (70 Words)
passage: Now, the study of biology is responsible for some of the most profound insights that humans have, about the world around them. So, take a look at these four panoramas. In the upper left, you see some bacteria this happen to be E Coli, you obviously see a butterfly, a flower, a dolphin. If you see that at the outer space, just looks these different forms and structures. You have no idea that they were all related to one to another. So one of the most profound thing that biology told us is that all life on earth is exceptionally related, similar to one to another. So, for example, all of these life forms rely on DNA and RNA for storing and transmitting in using their genetic and inherited information. They are all based on cell. Cell is the fundamental building blocks of all life. All of these organisms consist of cells, and the cells essentially have the same chemicals inside of them - carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen, and the whole bunch of other stuff and much smaller amount. All these organisms conducted metabolism, in other words, chemical reactions that using convert energy from one form to another. And the basic chemistry is all very similar to one and another. The types of molecule is used very similar to one and another.

  • All these organisms conducted metabolism, in other words, chemical reactions that using convert energy from one form to another. 所有这些生物都进行了新陈代谢，换句话说，就是利用化学反应将能量从一种形式转化为另一种形式。

title: Organization study（两个男声对话）
answer: Sample answer: Organization studies seem to draw on the whole family of disciplines, such as social science, psychology, sociology, and economics, anthropology, politics. The speaker enjoys studying organization study because of its broad range and its breadth. He also points out that organization studies are actually the artificiality of those academic subdivisions. What organization study has taught him is liberating ideas without strictures and disciplinary boundaries. (64 words)
passage:
Organization studies seem to draw on the whole family of Social Sciences, clearly psychology, clearly sociology, but also economics, anthropology, politics, as we said, philosophy to a degree history sometimes read literary studies, cultural citizen, so on and so forth. Yeah, I think that's absolutely right. And for me, that's absolutely the pleasure and even on good days, the joy of doing organization studies, because it enables you not just enables, but requires you, in sense, to have some kind of broad familiarization of that sort.
Now, there's a price to be paid for that because that kind of breadth, if you like, does come, I suppose as the cost of depth And I guess there would be people who are clearly within academic disciplines of sociology or economics or whatever, who might say, well, these are sort of magpie-ish, amateurish kind of forays into our territory. You know, I wouldn't necessarily disown that idea. But I think that what studying organizations teaches us and teaches me is actually the artificiality of those academic subdivisions. As soon as we start, we'll actually think about something like the organized world then immediately, the kinds of things that come into focus are things that have traditionally been studied by different demands. And so, I think it's a liberating idea, the idea that we don't need to be bound by those strictures and structures of disciplinary division, and that we can be free actually to imagine and think about the social world through an agglomeration of techniques and ideas and theories and concepts from across the social sciences.

title: Industrial revolution V2 真题音频
answer: Sample answer: The view of industrialization as beginning a situation of winners and losers has been rejected, because the Industrial Revolution is measured by more than simply large factories with industrial workers and the number of machines. Moreover, the Industrial Revolution was first and foremost an intensification of forms of production. In general, the rapid rise in industrial production was very tied to traditional forms of production. (65 words)
passage: Through the 1950s and into the 1960s, the idea of the Industrial Revolution was that it was the work of some genius inventors who created machines used primarily in the textile industry but also in mining that eliminated blocks to assembly line production. Then everybody was crowded into factories and the new brave world opened up. In fact, one of the most interesting books and great classics that is still in print was written by an economic historian at Harvard who's still alive called David Landes. It's a good book called The Unbound Prometheus, which was basically that. Some of the inventions that I briefly describe in your reading, the spinning Jenny, etc, refer to that. Well, and that kind of analysis led one to concentrate on England where the Industrial Revolution began, and to view industrialization as beginning a situation of winners and losers by not going as fast. Now, that analysis has been really rejected greatly over the past years, because Industrial Revolution is measured by more than simply large factories with industrial workers and the number of machines. This is the point of the beginning of this. The more that we look at the Industrial Revolution, the more that we see that the Industrial Revolution was first and foremost an intensification of forms of production, of kinds of production that were already there. And thus, we spend more time looking at, you know, the intensification of artisanal production, craft production, of domestic industry, which we've already mentioned, that is people mostly women but also men and children, too, working in the countryside. The rapid rise of industrial production was very much tied to traditional forms of production.

中文逻辑：

主题：工业化 （industrialization）是一种有赢有输 （winners and losers）的局面的观点被否定了（rejected）---原因1：衡量工业革命的不仅仅是拥有产业工人（industrial workers）和机器数量的大工厂（large factories）-------原因2：工业革命首先是一种生产形式的集约化（intensification）---结论：工业生产的快速增长与传统生产形式 （traditional forms of production）密切相关。

翻译：

  • Through the 1950s and into the 1960s, the idea of the Industrial Revolution was that it was the work of some genius inventors who created machines used primarily in the textile industry but also in mining that eliminated blocks to assembly line production. 从20世纪50年代到60年代，工业革命的理念是，一些天才发明家创造了主要用于纺织工业和采矿的机器，消除了装配线生产的障碍。

  • Then everybody was crowded into factories and the new brave world opened up. 接着，所有人都挤进了工厂，一个崭新的美丽世界就此展开。

  • In fact, one of the most interesting books and great classics that is still in print was written by an economic historian at Harvard who's still alive called David Landes. 事实上，至今仍在出版的最有趣、最伟大的著作之一是由哈佛大学的经济历史学家大卫·兰德斯所写，他现在还健在。

  • It's a good book called The Unbound Prometheus, which was basically that. 这本好书叫《被释放的普罗米修斯》基本上就是这样。

  • Some of the inventions that I briefly describe in your reading, the spinning Jenny, etc, refer to that. 我在你们的阅读材料中简要描述的一些发明，如珍妮纺纱机等，就是指这个。

  • Well, and that kind of analysis led one to concentrate on England where the Industrial Revolution began, and to view industrialization as beginning a situation of winners and losers by not going as fast. 这种分析让人们将注意力集中在工业革命开始的英国，并将工业化看作是一种胜者和败者的局面。

  • Now, that analysis has been really rejected greatly over the past years, because Industrial Revolution is measured by more than simply large factories with industrial workers and the number of machines. 在过去的几年里，这种分析遭到了很大的反对，因为工业革命不仅仅是由拥有产业工人和机器数量的大型工厂来衡量的。

  • This is the point of the beginning of this. 这是开始的一点。

  • The more that we look at the Industrial Revolution, the more that we see that the Industrial Revolution was first and foremost an intensification of forms of production, of kinds of production that were already there. 我们越是关注工业革命，就越会发现工业革命首先是一种生产形式的强化，一种已经存在的生产形式的强化。

  • And thus, we spend more time looking at, you know, the intensification of artisanal production, craft production, of domestic industry, which we've already mentioned, that is people mostly women but also men and children, too, working in the countryside. 因此，我们花了更多的时间来研究，你知道，手工生产的集约化，家庭工业的生产，我们已经提到过，在农村工作的大部分是妇女，也有男人和孩子。

  • The rapid rise of industrial production was very much tied to traditional forms of production. 工业生产的迅速发展与传统生产形式密切相关。

title: Australian public transport
postContent: Sample answer: Australian living patterns need cars as most Australians live in countryside and it will be inconvenient for them to work without a car. Only 20% of people in Australia cannot drive, mainly the elderly, young students or the disabled. Thus, Australian government should pay more attention to those who do not drive. Australian public transportation system in rural areas is not yet satisfactory, but it may lead to other problems. (70 words)

title: Language acquisition 真题音频
answer: Sample answer:Language acquisition starts earlier than most people think and it also ends later than most people think. It is hard to define when child language acquisition stops, for we stay being children all in our lives. Overall, two ends of child language acquisition are wider apart than some people think, which means there is more scope for studying in it than most people think. (64 words)
passage: Child language acquisition, three little words. So let's take them on at a time. Child, when to start being a child? For many people, language acquisition starts around about twelve months when kids say that first word, but don't forget the first year. title: Basic vocabulary 真题音频
answer: Sample answer:The basic vocabulary can be described as notions that are comparable and that occur everywhere in the world. For instance, all language of the world have words for body organ, appellation and other nouns, while it becomes vaguer because one word may present different meanings in different cultures. Therefore, you take basic vocabularies and languages that you think are related and look for words that sound the same. (68 words)
passage:
https://upclose.unimelb.edu.au/episode/127-ocean-away-african-nation-s-roots-southeast-asia [4:00 - 5:02]
Well, a historical linguist compares languages at several levels. You start out looking for basic vocabulary. All languages of the world, natural languages at least, have words for eye and head and nose and ear and for sky and earth and for water, sand and for sibling, mother and father. They may not have words for uncle and aunt. It becomes much vaguer because in one culture an aunt is different when it comes from your father's side than from your mother's side. You don't include snow. Most people know what snow is but in the tropics you don't have it. So you look for notions that are totally comparable and that occur everywhere in the world. You take the hundred or two hundred most universal notions in a human life, those which you call the basic vocabulary. So you take basic vocabularies and languages that you think are related. You look for words that sound the same.

中文逻辑：

主题：基本词汇（basic vocabulary） 可以被描述为可比较的（comparable ）概念---例子：世界上所有的语言（language） 都有表示身体器官 （body organ）、名称和其他名词的词，但由于一个词在不同的文化中（cultures）可能呈现不同的含义，它变得更加模糊（vaguer） ---结论：你要学习你认为相关的基本词汇和语言，并寻找发音相同（sound the same）的单词。

翻译:

  • Well, a historical linguist compares languages at several levels. 历史语言学家在几个层面上比较语言。

  • You start out looking for basic vocabulary. 你开始寻找基本的词汇。

  • All languages of the world, natural languages at least, have words for eye and head and nose and ear and for sky and earth and for water, sand and for sibling, mother and father. 世界上所有的语言，至少是自然语言，都有表示眼睛、头、鼻子、耳朵、天、地、水、沙、兄弟姐妹、母亲和父亲的词语。

  • They may not have words for uncle and aunt. 他们可能不会和叔叔阿姨说话。

  • It becomes much vaguer because in one culture an aunt is different when it comes from your father's side than from your mother's side. 因为在一种文化中，阿姨来自于你的父亲，而不是来自于你的母亲，所以这就变得很模糊了。

  • You don't include snow. 你不包括雪。

  • Most people know what snow is but in the tropics you don't have it. 大多数人都知道雪是什么，但在热带没有雪。

  • So you look for notions that are totally comparable and that occur everywhere in the world. 所以你要找的概念是完全可比的，而且在世界各地都有。

  • You take the hundred or two hundred most universal notions in a human life, those which you call the basic vocabulary. 你把人类生活中最普遍的一百个或两百个概念，那些你称之为基本词汇的东西。

  • So you take basic vocabularies and languages that you think are related. 所以你要学习一些你认为相关的基本词汇和语言。

  • You look for words that sound the same. 你要找发音相同的词。

title: The history of software 真题音频
answer: Sample answer:The whole IT industry is only 67 years old which is extraordinary. Due to Moore's Law, the rapid expansion in the power and the rapid fall of the cost and communications have made it feasible for information technology to move into all sorts of areas of life that were never originally envisaged. Overall, this is what's guided the development of software and information technology. (68 words)
passage:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=94IXRNQqdJc 
The history of software is of course very very new. And the whole IT industry is really only 67 years old which is extraordinary and to be so close to the birth of a major new technology, a major new discipline is quite remarkable given where we got to in those 67 years. And the progression has been not so much a progression as a stampede because Moore's Law, the rapid expansion in the power of computing and the rapid fall of the cost of computing and storage and communications has made it feasible for information technology to move into all sorts of areas of life that were never originally envisaged. What has happened is that there has been as I said a stampede for people to pick the low-hanging fruit. And that is what's guided the development of software and information technology over the past decades and continues to do so with a number of consequences that we will explore.
postContent:
原文：
The history of software is of course, very, very new. The whole I.T. industry is really only 60, 70 years old, which is extraordinary to be so close to the birth of a major new technology, a major new discipline is quite remarkable given where we got to in those 60, 70 years and under progression has been not so much a progression as a stampede because Moore's Law. The rapid expansion in the power of computing and the rapid fall of the cost of computing and storage and communications has made it feasible for information technology to move into all sorts of areas of life that were never originally envisaged. What has happened is that there has been, as I said, a stampede for people to pick the low hanging fruit. And that is what has guided the development of software and information technology over the past decades and continues to do so with a number of consequences that we will explore.

TIPS: 摩尔定律是由Intel创始人之一Gordon Moore提出来的。其表达的内容简言之是：每一美元所能买到的电脑性能，将每隔18-24个月翻一倍以上。这一定律揭示了信息技术进步的速度。

title: Transportation network in Paris
answer: Sample answer: There are a number of possible purposes for a social network. Network is a social relationship which helps transfer information, and it also helps people get to different destinations more quickly. It is suitable for old cities with high-density population like Paris. The transportation network in Paris provides thousands of public services and links them together. A good network can help people with long-distance or multi-destination trips. (67 words)

There are thousands of trips and too many travelers everyday in Paris. The transportation network in Parisprovidesthousands ofpublic servicesand links them together. postContent:
原文：

There are a number of possible purposes for a social network. You now have a good understanding of how to analyze the basic characteristics of your social network or that of another individual. Network is a social relationship which helps transfer information such as travelling from one place to another. It also helps people get to different destinations more quickly if they need to travel in a long distance or two destinations. It is suitable for old cities with high-density population like Paris. There are thousands of trips and too many travelers everyday in Paris. The transportation network in Paris provides thousands of public services and links them together. A good network can help people with long-distance or multi-destination trips. In cities with high-density population such as Paris, people would better carefully plan their journeys by looking at the routes of the network in advance, to reduce the density of commuters at the same time.

中文逻辑：

主题：社会网络（social networks）——社会网络有很多的用处——它的目的是帮助传递信息(transfer information) 的社会关系, 它也帮助人们能够更快达到不同的目的地（destination）——非常适合想巴黎这样的人口稠密（high-density)的老城市，巴黎的交通网络提供成千上万的公共服务并将它们连接在一起。一个好的网络可以帮助人们进行长途(long-distance)旅行或多目的地（multi-destination）旅行。

翻译：

  • You now have a good understanding of how to analyze the basic characteristics of your social network or that of another individual. 你现在已经很好地理解了如何分析你的社会网络或另一个人的基本特征。

  • Network is a social relationship which helps transfer information such as travelling from one place to another. 网络是一种社会关系，它帮助传递信息，如从一个地方到另一个地方旅行。

  • It also helps people get to different destinations more quickly if they need to travel in a long distance or two destinations. 它还可以帮助人们更快地到达不同的目的地，如果他们需要长途旅行或两个目的地。

  • It is suitable for old cities with high-density population like Paris. 适合像巴黎这样人口稠密的老城市。

  • There are thousands of trips and too many travelers everyday in Paris. 每天有成千上万的旅行和太多的旅行者在巴黎。

  • The transportation network in Paris provides thousands of public services and links them together. 巴黎的交通网络提供成千上万的公共服务并将它们连接在一起。

  • A good network can help people with long-distance or multi-destination trips. 一个好的网络可以帮助人们进行长途旅行或多目的地旅行。

  • In cities with high-density population such as Paris, people would better carefully plan their journeys by looking at the routes of the network in advance, to reduce the density of commuters at the same time. 在像巴黎这样人口稠密的城市，人们可以通过提前查看路网的路线来更好地规划自己的行程，同时减少通勤者的密度。

title: Why should we read the Republic 真题音频
answer: Sample answer： There are two reasons why students should read the Republic at the beginning of their university course. The first one is that this book is immensely readable, for Plato wrote is like a living conversation instead of a dry textbook. On the other hand, there are also obviously the thoughts. Plato asked fundamental question that is why people should be good, and this book will give the answer.
passage: Why should we read the Republic? I met lots of students asked this question to themselves when they're given it as a set of books at the beginning of their university course. But in fact, there are many good reasons to read the republic. And the first one I would pick on is just that it is immensely readable. It's not Plato did not write philosophy like a dry textbook. He wrote it like a living conversation. The whole of the Republic which is a fairly fat book is a living conversation written in short almost soundbite type answers, but nevertheless, developing some very very important ideas. So, my first answer then we should read the Republic just because it is readable. It is readable it was written by a genius and it's worth reading. It's easy to read. It's not difficult. But then there's also obviously the thoughts, the content of the book and he's asking this absolutely fundamental question "why should we bother to be good?" "what's in it for us effectively?". It seems when we look at the world, it looks as though injustice pays. It looks as though crime pays whereas the good people get trodden down. So, Plato addresses this absolutely fundamental question "why should we be good". I'm not going to tell you his answer. Read the book.

title: Industrial revolution 真题音频
answer: Sample answer: France's relation to 'retarded' is rejected because the Industrial Revolution is measured more than large factories and numbers of machines. Significantly, Industrial Revolution was an intensification of production. And the rapid rise of industrial production was very much tied to traditional forms of production. So, if people only focus on the factories and machine numbers, they will miss the boat on the Industrial Revolution. (68 words)
passage: France, one thought that they were called them "retarded", a word that was used, unfortunately, at that time. And then one tried to see why not. Now, that analysis has been really rejected greatly over the past years, because Industrial Revolution is measured by more than simply large factories with industrial workers and the number of machines. This is the point of the beginning of this. The more that we look at the Industrial Revolution, the more that we see that the Industrial Revolution was first and foremost an intensification of forms of production, of kinds of production that were already there. And thus, we spend more time looking at, you know, the intensification of artisanal production, craft production, of domestic industry, which we've already mentioned, that is people mostly women but also men and children, too, working in the countryside. The rapid rise of industrial production was very much tied to traditional forms of production. In paris, for example, in 1871, alright, 1870, the average unit of production had only slightly more than seven people in it. So, if you only look for big factories and lots of machines, you'll be missing the boat on the Industrial Revolution.

title: Implicit and Explicit memory (RL SST 同题，与原音频类似，可参考)
answer: Sample answer:The lecture is about two memories. Implicit memory is called procedural memory which cannot be consciously recalled. It is informed by cultural and social background. We are not aware when we use implicit memory since behaviors are automatic, such as using languages. Explicit memory is called bad memory and is known as episodic memory. It is related to time, space and personal life experience, such as remembering birthday. （68words）
passage: There are two main categories of memory. Implicit memory, which is also called procedural memory, cannot be consciously recalled. It is an experimental or functional form of memory, informed by cultural and social background. With implicit memory, behaviors are automatic. We recall implicit memories naturally, so we are not aware when we are using them. Examples of implicit memory include using languages naturally, driving automatically, reading and writing. When people try to consciously describe how to drive, they may misrepresent how they actually drive. What we often describe as ‘bad memory' is an explicit memory. Explicit memory is also known as episodic memory, which is totally different from implicit memory. It's more about time and space and is often related to personal life experiences. Some examples of explicit memory include remembering birthdays from many years ago or answering multiple-choice questions in a test.

It is an experimental or functional form of memory, informed by cultural and social background. With implicit memory, behaviors are automatic. We recall implicit memories naturally, so we are not aware when we are using them. Examples of implicit memory include using languages naturally, driving automatically, reading and writing. When people try to consciously describe how to drive, they may misrepresent how they actually drive.
What we often describe as ‘bad memory’ is an explicit memory. Explicit memory is also known as episodic memory, which is totally different from implicit memory. It’s more about time and space and is often related to personal life experiences. Some examples of explicit memory include remembering birthdays from many years ago or answering multiple-choice questions in a test.

中文逻辑：

主题：两种记忆（memories）------类型1：内隐记忆（ Implicit memory）被称为程序记忆procedural memory），是一种不能被有意识地回忆（recalled）的记忆-----类型2：外显记忆 （Explicit memory ）被称为不良记忆，被称为情景记忆（episodic memory），与时间、空间（space ）和个人生活经历（personal life experience）

翻译：

  • There are two main categories of memory. 记忆主要分为两类。

  • Implicit memory, which is also called procedural memory, cannot be consciously recalled. 内隐记忆又称程序记忆，不能被有意识地回忆。

  • It is an experimental or functional form of memory, informed by cultural and social background. 它是一种实验性的或功能性的记忆形式，受文化和社会背景的影响。

  • With implicit memory, behaviors are automatic. 对于内隐记忆，行为是自动的。

  • We recall implicit memories naturally, so we are not aware when we are using them. 我们会很自然地回忆内隐记忆，所以我们在使用它们的时候并没有意识到。

  • Examples of implicit memory include using languages naturally, driving automatically, reading and writing. 内隐记忆的例子包括自然地使用语言、自动驾驶、阅读和写作。

  • When people try to consciously describe how to drive, they may misrepresent how they actually drive. 当人们试图有意识地描述如何开车时，他们可能会误解他们实际是如何开车的。

  • What we often describe as ‘bad memory’ is an explicit memory. 我们常说的“糟糕的记忆”是一种外显记忆。

  • Explicit memory is also known as episodic memory, which is totally different from implicit memory. 外显记忆又称情景记忆，与内隐记忆完全不同。

  • It’s more about time and space and is often related to personal life experiences. 它更多的是关于时间和空间，通常与个人生活经历有关。

  • Some examples of explicit memory include remembering birthdays from many years ago or answering multiple-choice questions in a test. 外显记忆的一些例子包括记住许多年前的生日或在测试中回答多项选择题。

title: The market economy 真题音频
answer: Sample answer: Notions of pragmatism and democracies tempered the market economy. The Industrial Revolution had a negative effect on the working class with reduced life expectancy and living standards. However, people passed legislation about working conditions, and they circumscribed the worst behaviors. Then, the regulations composed better environmental conditions, which reversed the bad situations and made the market economy work. Finally, there are lots of benefits for people. (69 words)
passage: Within most developed countries, notions of pragmatism, notions of the fact that we have democracies, have succeeded in tempering the market economy. In the 19th century, 18th century, the Industrial Revolution has a very negative effect on people, particularly working classes all over the world. We see data where life expectancy was reduced, hikes we were reduced, we were looking at the medical record, and see the actually living standards, much among large fractions of population, actually went down. But eventually, we pass the legislation about working conditions. And eventually, we circumscribe some of the worst kinds of behavior. We eventually, in the 20th century, we put regulations that composed better environmental conditions. And so some of the damage was reversed, and that we have made the market economy work and ways that the benefits of the all are far more what we shared in the world a hundred years ago.

翻译：

  • Within most developed countries, notions of pragmatism, notions of the fact that we have democracies, have succeeded in tempering the market economy. 在大多数发达国家，实用主义的概念，我们有民主的概念，成功地调和了市场经济。

  • In the 19th century, 18th century, the Industrial Revolution has a very negative effect on people, particularly working classes all over the world. 在19、18世纪，工业革命对人们，特别是世界各地的工人阶级产生了非常负面的影响。

  • We see data where life expectancy was reduced, hikes we were reduced, we were looking at the medical record, and see the actually living standards, much among large fractions of population, actually went down. 我们看到数据显示预期寿命缩短了，增长减少了，我们查看医疗记录，看到实际生活水平，很大一部分人口的生活水平，实际上下降了。

  • But eventually, we pass the legislation about working conditions. 但最终，我们通过了有关工作条件的立法。

  • And eventually, we circumscribe some of the worst kinds of behavior. 最终，我们限定了一些最恶劣的行为。

  • We eventually, in the 20th century, we put regulations that composed better environmental conditions. 最终，在20世纪，我们制定了改善环境条件的法规。

  • And so some of the damage was reversed, and that we have made the market economy work and ways that the benefits of the all are far more what we shared in the world a hundred years ago. 因此，一些损害被扭转了，我们已经使市场经济运作起来，所有人的利益都比100年前我们在世界上分享的更多。

title: Western Europe 真题音频
answer: Sample answer:The weather in Europe and in many parts of the world took a turn for the worse at the end of the Old Stone Age, while the question is where did people travel to escape the worst of the weather. It could be that humans lived on exposed shores during the Paleolithic, but we have no evidence of their settlements because of fall of sea levels. (66words)
passage:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B4Mg6Dnarx0 [0.23-1.48]
23,000 years ago, towards the end of the Old Stone Age, also known as the upper Paleolithic, the weather in Europe and in many parts of the world took a turn for the worse. Temperatures plummeted, rain levels fell and a massive ice sheet slowly advanced to cover most of northern Europe and stay there for the next few thousand years. We know that during this glacial period, many animal and plant species sought shelter in Europe's three warmer southern peninsulas, Iberia, Italy, and the Balkans. But the question is, where did the people go? Archaeological material recovered from this time period has shown that a large number of our ancestors retreated to Franco Cantabria, an area covering the southwest of France and the northeastern tip of Spain. But was this the only area where people traveled to escape the worst of the weather? Let's go back to the growing ice sheet. In order to grow, the ice mass had to take up water, causing sea levels to fall. At its maximum when the ice reached as far south as Germany, sea levels were up to 120 meters lower than today. That's approximately the same height as the London Eye. As a result, areas of the shallow sea became exposed and Europe's shape was very different from the one we recognized. It could be that humans lived on these exposed shores during the Paleolithic, but we have no evidence of their settlements because it's now we're underwater.

title: Young people communities
answer: Sample answer: The topic is about the research on a wide range of young students and children. It is about how they participate in their communities, how they form value with character education, and the outcomes involve parents, siblings and schools. Researchers figure out which factors are essential and more important than others. The research has also attracted attention and interest from many politicians. (62 words)
passage: 原文：A research in the UK on a wide range of young students and children is abouthow they participate in their communities, how they form values with character education and what influence them most. The outcomes involve parents, friends, schools and siblings, and researchers figure out which factors are essential and more important than others.Successful schools depend on the resources and support of their communities and schools at the centre of their communities are often the most successful schools. In turn,schools are vital to the social health of their local communities. Also, families are the first social unit in which children learn and develop. Good parenting can take different forms and be shaped by various social and cultural forces, but it invariably involves providingchildren with the support, care, love, guidance and protection that set the conditions for healthy physical, mental and social development. The research has also attracted attention and interest from many national policy makers and contacted me.
kword: Students,student, children, communities,community, value, character, education, parents,parent, sibling,siblings, attention
postContent:
原文：

Research in the UK on a wide range of young students and children is about how they participate in their communities, how they form values with character education and what influence them most. The outcomes involve parents, friends, schools and siblings, and researchers figure out which factors are essential and more important than others. Successful schools depend on the resources and support of their communities and schools at the centre of their communities are often the most successful schools. In turn, schools are vital to the social health of their local communities. Also, families are the first social unit in which children learn and develop. Good parenting can take different forms and be shaped by various social and cultural forces, but it invariably involves providing children with the support, care, love, guidance and protection that set the conditions for healthy physical, mental and social development. The research has also attracted attention and interest from many national policymakers and contacted me.
postContentFiltered:
中文逻辑：

主题：对年轻学生（young students）和孩子的研究的研究——研究内容：关于他们如何参与 （participate） 他们的社区（communities），如何形成价值（value）和品格教育（character education）——研究结果：涉及父母、兄弟姐妹（siblings） 和学校——成功的学校（successful school）依赖资源，学校对于当地社区的社会健康(social health)至关重要。 家庭是儿童的第一个社会单位(social unit)——人们人们找出（figure out）哪些是必要的（essential） 研究，这也吸引了（attracted） 许多政治家的关注（attention） 和兴趣。

翻译：

  • Research in the UK on a wide range of young students and children is about how they participate in their communities, how they form values with character education and what influence them most. 英国对青少年学生和儿童进行了广泛的研究，研究内容包括他们如何参与社区活动，如何通过品格教育形成价值观，以及什么对他们的影响最大。

  • The outcomes involve parents, friends, schools and siblings, and researchers figure out which factors are essential and more important than others. 研究结果涉及到父母、朋友、学校和兄弟姐妹，研究人员找出了哪些因素是必不可少的，比其他因素更重要。

  • Successful schools depend on the resources and support of their communities and schools at the centre of their communities are often the most successful schools. 成功的学校依赖于其社区的资源和支持，而位于社区中心的学校往往是最成功的学校。

  • In turn, schools are vital to the social health of their local communities. 反过来，学校对当地社区的社会健康也至关重要。

  • Also, families are the first social unit in which children learn and develop. 此外，家庭是儿童学习和发展的第一个社会单位。

  • Good parenting can take different forms and be shaped by various social and cultural forces, but it invariably involves providing children with the support, care, love, guidance and protection that set the conditions for healthy physical, mental and social development. 良好的养育方式可以采取不同的形式，并受到各种社会和文化力量的影响，但它总是涉及向儿童提供支持、照顾、爱、指导和保护，为健康的身体、心理和社会发展创造条件。

  • The research has also attracted attention and interest from many national policymakers and contacted me. 该研究也引起了许多国家政策制定者的关注和兴趣，并联系了我。

The outcomes involve parents, friends, schools and siblings, and researchers figure out which factors are essential and more important than others. Successful schools depend on the resources and support of their communities and schools at the centre of their communities are often the most successful schools. In turn, schools are vital to the social health of their local communities. Also, families are the first social unit in which children learn and develop. title: Internet
postContent: Sample answer: The Internet has the most complicated structure and is the most powerful tool in terms of engineering. The internet can be connected to a MODEM, or an ADSL switch, and then to a local landline telephone exchange. It can connect us from Sydney to Melbourne and then to the US through cables. However, information transmission requires energy. For example, the longer email you write, the more energy is consumed. (69 words)

title: Management V2

title: The Travels of Sir John Mandeville
answer: Sample answer: ‘Travels of Sir John Mandeville' was more popular than the book of Marco Polo. It is a guide for the travelling and distant lands and describes his supposed travels to the Mid East, Africa and Asia. Although its descriptions were not true, it only shows how European people thought about foreign lands and civilizations outside Europe, and all these are mysterious, alluring and intimidating, unknown. (67 words)
passage: But if you were to go to a library at the end of the 1300s, or through the 1400s, you would probably find a book that was then, way more popular than those titles we still read, a book that purported to be a description of the world, a guide for the traveling and distant lands of BC area and Almanac of everything that was just off the horizon. I am not talking about Marco Polo. No, I'm talking about something far far, weirder and far, far less tethered to reality, a volume of medieval fantasy masquerading as a field guide called The travels of Sir John Mandeville, supposedly the titular night set out from England in the 1330s and embarked on a journey that would take him to the Middle East, Africa and Asia, though as it will become apparent, not a Middle East, not in Africa and not an Asia that we would recognize here in reality. No Mandeville spoke is not really about actually real foreign lands. It's about what Europeans thought was just outside the bounds of their civilizations. It's about what's beyond that mountain range that marks the borders of the lands you know. It's about what medieval people thought the foreign looks like. And all these are mysterious, alluring and intimidating, unknown.

title: Design of building
postContent: 回忆要点：Design is relatively important to building due to the fact that they may not only impact its appearance, but also affect health conditions. For example, the design of ground floors must ensure that the building is able to withstand the weight of the higher levels. There are poorly designed building but also some great building works. In the 20th century, many building were demolished, which should be decided based its nature and function.

title: The utility of negative emotions
postContent: Sample answer: The lecture talks about the utility of negative emotions. The fact that people pay more attention to negative emotion called negativity bias. Firstly, the negative things such as fears promote evolution and help people to survive in life-threatening issues. And the positive things that we frequently experience is limiting, but the negative emotions are less frequently but very intensive. (59 words)

title: Background of waterfalls
postContent:
回忆要点1：考到一个新题，background of waterfalls. In Chinatown, they are common creations. 中间提到需要famers，famers destroy什么, 后面说They are vital habitats for migration birds. 最后一句说什么doubled。

回忆要点2：water usage in agriculture. The demand exceeds supply. Farmers conflict with finite resources. Water is derived from a lake which is become habitats for birds migration.

title: Languages and vocabularies
postContent:
回忆要点：Different languages and cultures, vocabulary is one of the most interesting characters, because different cultures may have different vocabularies. For example, in some language there is no “uncle” or “aunt” because they differ between mother’s side and father’s side. Another example is that some languages don’t have “snow” in their vocabularies because people of those culture live in tropical areas.

回忆要点2：The levels of language. 关键词听到了the natural level of language like English. there are some words, earth, father, mother. English is a kind of neo-latin. uncle, aunt, there words are different at mother side and father side in some language. Vocabulary is important for the level of language. 主要就这个意思，中间有好多单个的单词作为他这个vocabulary的例子

title: Twelve incorrect experiments
postContent: 回忆要点：A book about 12 incorrect scientific phenomena and experiments, the real science may not be what thought it would be because successful science experiments may be boring. These 12 failed experiments are very interesting because each has a different reason. For example, an experiment could fail because of made-up numbers.

title: Multiculturalism in Australia
postContent: Sample answer: Being a multicultural country, Australia has migrations from all over the world. Australia has one of the world’s oldest continuous cultures. Nearly a half of the Australian population were born overseas or have a foreign-born parent. Migrants’ contributions to Australian’s economy are enormous as estimation shows over 10 billion of fiscal benefit was provided in their first 10 years of settlement.(66 words)

title: Network

title: Language learning
postContent:
回忆要点1：language learning， 说的是 the important of early star，大部分内容说的是 12个月内的孩子学语言很重要。甚至before born, 中间还说了 不要在意语法啥的 我的麦声音突然很小。我去调整下，就没了。 只听到最后一句是 It is much important than you think and it is a vital part for children.

回忆要点2：我听到的标题发音是language accrusation，但是不确定。除了说language learning starts before born，还说了language accruzation ends later than people expected, there is no clear end，除了sounds，grammar and vocabulary都需要花很长时间去学习。最后好像还说了language accruzation is wider than people expected

回忆要点3：反复重复的主题词acquiring a language 说人们start acquiring a language earlier than we expected baby的时候就开始甚至出生前就有语言意识 1岁是最重要的时候 开始发出声音 后来我们开始学习grammar vocabulary 这两个我们以后也一直在学 有人甚至rest of life都在学习词汇 所以学习语言的end time也later than we excepted. we actually have a wider scope of acquiring a language.

title: The history of English
answer: Sample answer: English is not a pure language, because it has borrowed from over 350 languages in its history. We learn about the history of the English as well as that of the English people since the two are closely connected. The fact that English has borrowed words from over 350 languages has been viewed differently throughout history.(56 words)
passage: English, as you have already read, is not a pure language. I don't think there really are any pure languages in the world. But English is definitely not a pure language. English, in fact, has borrowed from over 350 languages in its history. So it's a variety of many languages. Some people say it's like a dog, a mongrel dog, a dog that has been made up of many different dogs. The English language is like that. By looking at the history of the English language we learn about the history of the English people. The two things are closely connected. So, in fact, today we are not only learning about language but we are learning about history. The fact that English has borrowed words from over 350 languages has been viewed differently throughout history. So for example in Shakespeare's time people were very angry about words which were not, they thought, original English words - words which came from other languages, they didn't like them.

翻译：

  • The English language is like that. 英语就是这样。

title: Talent war V2爷爷 真题音频
answer: Sample answer:This lecture talks about the talent. Because of the shortage in talent both within countries and between countries, there is an intense competition to hire the most talented and most intellectually able people. Therefore, countries are trying to lure bright young people to get them to go to universities and become immigrants. In conclusion, talent is a premium. (58 words)
passage: I think there is an intense competition at the moment to hire the most talented and the most intellectually able people. There is a time when I think companies have many of the adventures in the world. That involves the companies' world. It was the bosses' world. Now I think it reverses the case. We have a shortage of talent both within countries and between countries, have an intense battle between companies trying to hire the most talented workers and also between countries, which are looking to recruit talented young people, talented young immigrants. We have this sense of immigrants being things that countries are battled to keep out, and immigrants want to get in, climb over the walls. I think the opposite is in fact that the case. And the topic is that countries are trying to lure bright young people to get them to go to universities and get them to become immigrants. So, on many levels, talent is a premium. There is a shortage of talent, and so countries, companies, all sorts of organizations, of course, volunteer organizations as well as, are competing to hire the best and the brightest. You know we have a baby-boom population which is aging. We have an economy which is becoming more sophisticated. And so, for all those sorts of reasons, talent is a premium.

title: Email system (近似原文)
answer: Sample answer: The speaker talks about Internet and email system. Innovation like the Internet or email system have different characters which can be advantages and disadvantages, so they have more than one purpose. The email system was designed by graduate students and researchers who know and trust each other. Now, the email system was considered to be useful but not secure. So we need email authentication to be built into this system.（70 words)  答案和上述文章不完全一致，教研团队根据学员回忆修改，以答案为主
passage: Internet was invented by people who were good at programming, and people keep optimizing it for different purposes. So Internet has been growing organically. Internet can achieve many things but has advantages and disadvantages. The email system was designed by graduate students and researchers who know and trust each other. Using email needs trust between the senders and the receivers as the authentication process was not originally built in this system. Email authentication is a technical solution to proving that an email is not forged. In other words, it provides a way to verify that an email comes from whom it claims to be from. Email authentication is most often used to block harmful or fraudulent uses of email such as phishing and spam. In practice, we use the term “email authentication” to refer to technical standards that make this verification possible. Initially, the email system didn't consider security because there was no suspicion between them at that time, and there was no authentication process built into this system.
kword: Internet, email, character,characters, advantages, researcher,researchers, system, useful, secure,security, authentication

Email authentication is a technical solution to proving that an email is not forged. In other words, it provides a way to verify that an email comes from whom it claims to be from. Email authentication is most often used to block harmful or fraudulent uses of email such as phishing and spam. postContentFiltered:
中文逻辑：

主题：互联网（Internet）邮件系统(email system)——像互联网和邮件这样的创新（innovation）有不同的特性（characters），包括优点和缺点，所以他们的目的（purpose）也不只有一个——邮件系统是由大学生和研究人员设计，他们互相之间是认识和信任的（know and trust）—— 现在邮件系统被认为有用但是不安全（secure) ——所以我们需要电子邮箱认证（email authentication）设计在这个系统里。

翻译：

  • Internet was invented by people who were good at programming, and people keep optimizing it for different purposes. 互联网是由擅长编程的人发明的，人们为了不同的目的不断优化它。

  • So Internet has been growing organically. 因此，互联网一直在有机地发展。

  • Internet can achieve many things but has advantages and disadvantages. 互联网可以实现很多事情，但有优点和缺点。

  • The email system was designed by graduate students and researchers who know and trust each other. 电子邮件系统是由相互了解和信任的研究生和研究人员设计的。

  • Using email needs trust between the senders and the receivers as the authentication process was not originally built in this system. 使用电子邮件需要发送方和接收方之间的信任，因为该系统最初没有建立身份验证过程。

  • Email authentication is a technical solution to proving that an email is not forged. 电子邮件认证是一种证明电子邮件不是伪造的技术解决方案。

  • In other words, it provides a way to verify that an email comes from whom it claims to be from. 换句话说，它提供了一种方法来验证电子邮件来自它声称的发件人。

  • Email authentication is most often used to block harmful or fraudulent uses of email such as phishing and spam. 电子邮件认证最常用于阻止有害或欺诈性的电子邮件使用，如网络钓鱼和垃圾邮件。

  • In practice, we use the term “email authentication” to refer to technical standards that make this verification possible. 在实践中，我们使用术语“电子邮件身份验证”来指代使这种验证成为可能的技术标准。

  • Initially, the email system didn't consider security because there was no suspicion between them at that time, and there was no authentication process built into this system. 最初，电子邮件系统没有考虑安全性，因为当时他们之间没有相互怀疑，并且这个系统中没有内置认证过程。
delRedContent: Internet was invented by people who were good at programming, and people keep optimizing it for different purposes. So Internet has been growing organically. Internet can achieve many things but has advantages and disadvantages. The email system was designed by graduate students and researchers who know and trust each other. Using email needs trust between the senders and the receivers as the authentication process was not originally built in this system. Email authentication is a technical solution to proving that an email is not forged. In other words, it provides a way to verify that an email comes from whom it claims to be from. Email authentication is most often used to block harmful or fraudulent uses of email such as phishing and spam. In practice, we use the term “email authentication” to refer to technical standards that make this verification possible. Initially, the email system didn't consider security because there was no suspicion between them at that time, and there was no authentication process built into this system.

title: Motivation V2（近似原文）
answer: Sample answer: The lecture was described approach and avoidance motivation. Approach indicates a propensity to move toward a desired stimulus, while avoidance indicates a propensity to move away from an undesired stimulus. Motivation is defined as the energization and direction of behavior. The valence of stimuli is important to distinguish these two. Stimuli can be external or internal, implicit or explicit, conscious or non-conscious.(62 words)
passage: 近似原文：Approach and avoidance motivation is composed of three conceptually distinct components. Approach indicates a propensity to move toward (or maintain contact with) a desired stimulus, such as vocational plans. Avoidance indicates a propensity to move away from (or maintain distance from) an undesired stimulus in order to reduce anxiety. Motivation is defined as the energization and direction of behavior. The valence of stimuli is at the core of the distinction between approach and avoidance, with positively valenced stimuli typically leading to approach and negatively valenced stimuli typically leading to avoidance. Stimuli can be external or internal, implicit or explicit, conscious or non-conscious.

近似原文：
Approach and avoidance motivation is composed of three conceptually distinct components. Approach indicates a propensity to move toward (or maintain contact with) a desired stimulus, such as vocational plans. Avoidance indicates a propensity to move away from (or maintain distance from) an undesired stimulus in order to reduce anxiety. Motivation is defined as the energization and direction of behavior. The valence of stimuli is at the core of the distinction between approach and avoidance, with positively valenced stimuli typically leading to approach and negatively valenced stimuli typically leading to avoidance. Stimuli can be external or internal, implicit or explicit, conscious or non-conscious.

中文逻辑：

主题：动机描述为两种类型，它们是接近动机（approach motivation）和回避动机（avoidance motivation）——Approach表示倾向于倾向于一个想要的刺激（desired stimulus）——avoidance表示倾向于（propensity））远离一个不想要的刺激——动机是指对行为的激励（energization）和指导（direction ）——要区分这两者，刺激的效价是很重要的。——刺激可以是外部的或内部的（external or internal），内隐的或外显的（implicit or explicit），有意识的或无意识的（conscious or non-conscious）。

翻译：

  • Approach and avoidance motivation is composed of three conceptually distinct components. 趋近动机和回避动机由三个概念上不同的组成部分组成。

  • Approach indicates a propensity to move toward (or maintain contact with) a desired stimulus, such as vocational plans. “方法”指的是倾向于朝着(或与)期望的刺激(如职业计划)前进或保持联系。

  • Avoidance indicates a propensity to move away from (or maintain distance from) an undesired stimulus in order to reduce anxiety. 回避指的是一种倾向于远离(或保持距离)一个不希望的刺激，以减少焦虑。

  • Motivation is defined as the energization and direction of behavior. 动机是指对行为的激励和指导。

  • The valence of stimuli is at the core of the distinction between approach and avoidance, with positively valenced stimuli typically leading to approach and negatively valenced stimuli typically leading to avoidance. 刺激的效价是区分接近和回避的核心，积极的效价刺激通常导致接近，消极的效价刺激通常导致回避。

  • Stimuli can be external or internal, implicit or explicit, conscious or non-conscious. 刺激可以是外部的或内部的，内隐的或外显的，有意识的或无意识的。

title: The city of Rome 真题音频
answer: Sample answer: The city of Rome was built with crooked and narrow streets in a fairly ad hoc way. It was not planned all at once but grew up over time from the eighth century BC. Since Romans structured their city in a methodical way based on military strategy, and thus the ideal Roman city was shown in a castrum or military camp design. (62 words)
passage:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qd3MJPHaotQ&feature=share 
You can see from the relatively crooked and narrow streets of the city of Rome as they look from above today. You can see that again the city grew in a fairly ad hoc way as I mentioned it wasn't planned all at once. It just grew up over time beginning in the 8th century BC. Now this is interesting because what we know about the Romans is when they were left to their own devices, and they could build a city from scratch. They didn't let it grow in an ad hoc way. They structured it in a very very methodical way that was basically based on military strategy, military planning. The Romans they couldn't have conquered the world without obviously having a masterful military enterprise, and they everywhere they went on their various campaigns their various military campaigns. They would build camps and those camps were always laid out in a very geometric plan along the grid, usually square or rectangular. So when we begin to see the Romans building their ideal Roman city, they turn to that so-called castrum or military camp design.

title: Sign language(非原文，但是近似原文）
answer: Sample answer:Abstraction is an important layer of the computer. Human language is a classic symbolic system. Human used sign language before, but they wanted to communicate even while they were doing things, such as strangling the rhinoceros. So, it is very important to be able to do something with your hands and be able to communicate at the same time. In conclusion, this lecture mentioned sign language and words. (68 words)
passage: So the topic for today is abstraction. And this is a very important layer of computer because you can't do anything with a computer unless you have a symbolic system in place. Right. So we're talking about the origin of symbolic systems. Language is a classic symbolic system. Apparently one theory for why language evolved is that people communicated with sign language and with movement quite well for a long time. And it turned out that they wanted to communicate even while they were doing things. So, while they were trying to strangle the dinosaur, not the dinosaurs, the rhinoceros, they wanted to say"Come help me" and they use sign language to do it. They had to let go of the rhinoceros and the rhinoceros ran away. So you can see that it's a good idea to be able to do something with your hands and be able to communicate at the same time. Hence,words and language.

主题：手语（sign language）——抽象概念(abstraction)­是电脑中重要的层次（important layer）——人类语言（Human language）是一个经典的符号系统（classic symbolic system）——过去：人类以前使用手语（Sign language）——后来：人们希望能够用手做一些事情的同时能够交流——这就是为什么语言和文字出现。

翻译：
  • So the topic for today is abstraction. 今天的主题是抽象概念。
  • And this is a very important layer of computer because you can't do anything with a computer unless you have a symbolic system in place. 如果你没有一个恰当的符号系统，你不能用计算机做任何事情，所以这是计算机非常重要的一层。
  • Right. 好了。

    Language is a classic symbolic system. 语言是一个经典的符号系统。
  • Apparently one theory for why language evolved is that people communicated with sign language and with movement quite well for a long time. 显而易见，一个有关语言形成原因的理论是，人们很长一段时间都用手语和动作进行交流。
  • And it turned out that they wanted to communicate even while they were doing things. 结果是，他们甚至想在做事情的同时也可以交流。
  • So, while they were trying to strangle the dinosaur, not the dinosaurs, the rhinoceros, they wanted to say "Come help me" and they use sign language to do it. 所以当他们试图勒死恐龙的时候，不是恐龙，是犀牛，他们想说"来帮帮我"，这时他们需要用手语来交流。
  • They had to let go of the rhinoceros and the rhinoceros ran away. 他们不得不放开犀牛，然后犀牛就跑掉了。
    So you can see that it's a good idea to be able to do something with your hands and be able to communicate at the same time. 所以你可以预见，能同时用手做一些事情和沟通是一个好主意。
  • Hence, words and language. 所以单词和语言就产生了。

title: Food crisis（真题原文）
answer: Sample answer:People will suffer from a food crisis for the next 30 years, so immediate action should be taken. We should double our production to cater for the future demand. It is an urgent matter. So people should elevate the production. There is also an opportunity for developing countries to improve food systems alongside reducing poverty and increasing global resilience to shocks.(61 words)
passage: 原文：It is projected that people are going to suffer from a serious food crisisfor the next 30 years until 2030. Unless immediateaction is taken, it is increasingly clear thatthere is an impending global food emergency that could have long-term impacts on hundreds of millions of children and adults. We must double the yield of our production by increasing 100% to feed a growing global population and to cater for the future demand of food. This is an urgent matter and is quite frightening. About 50 million people risk falling into extreme poverty this year. People should elevate food productionnow. Scientists have predicted an increase in food production of 30% to 50% for developing countries in the next three years. There will be an increase of the cost of the production.There is also an opportunity for developing countries to improve food systems alongside reducing poverty and increasing global resilience to shocks.
kword: food, crisis, double, production, elevate,elevates, developing, system,systems, poverty, resilience
postContent:
原文： 

It is projected that people are going to suffer from a serious food crisis for the next 30 years until 2030. Unless immediate action is taken, it is increasingly clear that there is an impending global food emergency that could have long-term impacts on hundreds of millions of children and adults. We must double the yield of our production by increasing 100% to feed a growing global population and to cater for the future demand of food. This is an urgent matter and is quite frightening. About 50 million people risk falling into extreme poverty this year. People should elevate food production now. Scientists have predicted an increase in food production of 30% to 50% for developing countries in the next three years. There will be an increase of the cost of the production. There is also an opportunity for developing countries to improve food systems alongside reducing poverty and increasing global resilience to shocks.
postContentFiltered:
中文逻辑：

主题： 粮食生产和粮食危机之间的关系（the relationship between food production and food crisis）——人们将在未来30年遭受粮食危机（ suffer food crisis），直到2030年——需要立刻采取行动（actions）——为了满足未来的需求，我们应该把产量增加一倍（double）。这是紧急事件(urgent matter)——所以人们应该提高产量（elevate the production）。发展中国家也有机会改善粮食系统，同时减少贫困和增强全球抵御（global resilience）冲击的能力。

翻译：

  • It is projected that people are going to suffer from a serious food crisis for the next 30 years until 2030. 据预测，在未来的30年里，直到2030年，人们将遭受严重的粮食危机。

  • Unless immediate action is taken, it is increasingly clear that there is an impending global food emergency that could have long-term impacts on hundreds of millions of children and adults. 除非立即采取行动，否则越来越明显的是，全球粮食紧急情况即将出现，可能对数亿儿童和成人产生长期影响。

  • We must double the yield of our production by increasing 100% to feed a growing global population and to cater for the future demand of food. 我们必须通过增加100%的产量来养活不断增长的全球人口，并满足未来的粮食需求，使我们的产量翻一番。

  • This is an urgent matter and is quite frightening. 这是一件紧急的事情，非常可怕。

  • About 50 million people risk falling into extreme poverty this year. 今年大约有5000万人可能陷入极端贫困。

  • People should elevate food production now. 人们现在应该提高粮食产量。

  • Scientists have predicted an increase in food production of 30% to 50% for developing countries in the next three years. 科学家预测未来三年发展中国家的粮食产量将增加30%到50%。

  • There will be an increase of the cost of the production. 生产成本将会增加。

  • There is also an opportunity for developing countries to improve food systems alongside reducing poverty and increasing global resilience to shocks. 发展中国家也有机会改善粮食系统，同时减少贫困和增强全球抵御冲击的能力。

There will be an increase of the cost of the production. There is also an opportunity for developing countries to improve food systems alongside reducing poverty and increasing global resilience to shocks.

title: The definition of great idea
answer: Sample answer: The definition of a good idea varies depending on whom you ask. A great idea should have several features. Firstly, the great idea should be various and novel. Secondly, the great idea should be unique. Thirdly, it is essential for great ideas to be transformative and productive. And, an idea or a concept is unique when it transcends its predecessor and serves its purpose in a precise way.(62 words)
passage: 原文：To be a successful entrepreneur, you should have good ideas, but the definition of a good idea varies depending on whom you ask. A great idea should have several features. Firstly, the great idea should be various and novel. Secondly, the great idea should be unique, which means no one has thought about it. Thirdly, it is essential for great ideas to be transformative and productive. All ideas are essentially a combination of other smaller ideas, but this doesn't mean they can't be unique. Merely copying doesn't make anything idiosyncratic, its the individuality that one puts in which makes a concept stand out. Constant innovation leaves no room for stagnation and thus, adds on to the basic idea, effectively making it unique. Unique ideas are inspired by basic things, they are simply extensions of pre-existing notions. And, an idea or a concept is unique only when it transcends its predecessor and serves its purpose in a better and more precise way.

  • To be a successful entrepreneur, you should have good ideas, but the definition of a good idea varies depending on whom you ask. 要成为一名成功的企业家，你应该有好主意，但好主意的定义取决于你问的人。

title: Semantic Noise 真题音频
answer: Sample answer: Semantic noise in communication is a type of disturbance in the transmission of a message that interferes with the interpretation due to ambiguity in words, sentences or symbols. However, the ambiguity is caused because everybody sees a different meaning in the same things. The differences in interpretation can be small in communication between people from similar backgrounds or can be different because of the diversity of culture, age or experience. (70 words)
passage:
https://study.com/academy/lesson/semantic-noise-in-communication-definition-examples-quiz.html#lesson 
Semantic noise in communication is a type of disturbance in the transmission of a message that interferes with the interpretation of the message due to ambiguity in words, sentences or symbols used in the transmission of the message.
Let's take a step back for a moment to provide a larger framework that helps you understand the idea of semantic noise a bit easier. Communication is the process of transmitting information from one person to another. Information is a pattern of data organized in a particular way. For example, a sentence consists of symbols that form words in a particular language with a particular meaning. The sentence also utilizes grammar, which is a recognized way to structure words forming a sentence. Noise is any type of disturbance that interferes with the interpretation of the information. Some argue that noise exists in all communication.
Semantic noise doesn't involve sound but rather ambiguity in words, sentences or other symbols used in communication. The ambiguity is caused because everybody sees a different meaning in the same words, phrases or sentences. The differences in interpretation can be quite small, even undetectable, in regular communication between people from the same culture, age, education and experience, or drastically different because of such things as culture, age or experience.(最后一句话音频缺失, 但是重点内容，不能错过)

title: Earth and Mars
answer: Sample answer: Mars is an interesting planet which is not far away from the earth. The landscape and the geological surface of Mars are similar to the earth. There is not much atmosphere, but rare gases are found and an amount of water is found in icy form. Heavy gasses do not evaporate within a low gravity. There may be a thin layer of the atmosphere. Mars may be the ideal destination.(70 words)
passage: We are going to look at an very interesting and important place today. It is called the Mars which is not far away from the earth. Mars is an interesting neighboring planet to Earth with a similar geological surface and landscape, such as the desert, covered with rocks. Although there has not been evidence for the existence of water yet, the trace of heavy gases has existed on Mars for billions of years. Traces of a great amount of water in icy form just like mountains have been found. There is not much atmosphere, but rare gasses are still found. It is possibly because heavy gasses do not evaporate within a low gravity. The low gravity on Mars indicates that there may be a thin layer of the atmosphere on Mars. Therefore, Mars might be the most ideal destination other than Earth.
